title: German submarine U-669
text:
German submarine "U-669" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 3 November 1941 at the <a href="Howaldtswerke">Howaldtswerke</a> yard at <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 5 October 1942, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 16 December 1942 under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a> d.R." Kurt Köhl.
Attached to "<a href="5th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">5th U-boat Flotilla</a>" based at <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a>, "U-669" completed her training period on 31 May 1943 and was assigned to front-line service.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-669" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> GU 343/38–8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-669" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>s. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
On the second war patrol "U-669" went missing in the Bay of Biscay in August 1943. The U-boat had left <a href="St.%20Nazaire">St. Nazaire</a> on 29 August and had not been heard of since. Subsequently, "U-669" and her crew of 52 was declared missing on 8 September 1943.
